Literature Review: Sir Partha Dasgupta's contributions to environmental and development economics have been groundbreaking, shaping the field and influencing policy decisions worldwide. This literature review explores the key themes and impacts of Dasgupta's work, highlighting his innovative approaches to integrating environmental concerns with economic development.Dasgupta's early work focused on the economics of exhaustible resources, laying the foundation for modern resource economics. In their seminal paper, Dasgupta and Heal (1974) developed a model of optimal resource extraction that considered both economic growth and resource depletion. This work was instrumental in establishing the importance of natural capital in economic analysis and policy-making.Building on this foundation, Dasgupta has been a pioneer in ecological economics, emphasizing the critical role of ecosystem services in human well-being and economic sustainability. His research has highlighted the need to account for natural capital in national economic measures, arguing that traditional metrics like GDP fail to capture the true value of environmental resources (Dasgupta, 2021). This perspective has gained traction in recent years, with several countries now incorporating natural capital accounting into their national economic assessments (Lange et al., 2018).Dasgupta's work on the economics of biodiversity has been particularly influential. In a comprehensive review, he demonstrated the economic value of biodiversity and the potential costs of its loss (Dasgupta, 2019). This research has informed international efforts to protect biodiversity, including the Convention on Biological Diversity and the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES).In the realm of development economics, Dasgupta has made significant contributions to understanding the relationship between poverty, population growth, and environmental degradation. His research has shown that these factors are often interlinked, creating poverty traps that can be difficult to escape without targeted interventions (Dasgupta, 1997). This work has influenced development policies and programs worldwide, emphasizing the need for integrated approaches that address both economic and environmental concerns.Dasgupta's research on intergenerational equity and sustainability has also been groundbreaking. He has argued for the importance of considering future generations in current economic decision-making, developing frameworks for assessing the long-term impacts of resource use and environmental degradation (Arrow et al., 2012). This work has been influential in shaping discussions around sustainable development and climate change mitigation.In recent years, Dasgupta has focused on the concept of inclusive wealth as a more comprehensive measure of societal progress. This approach incorporates natural, human, and produced capital into a single metric, providing a more holistic view of a nation's wealth and sustainability (UNU-IHDP and UNEP, 2014). The inclusive wealth framework has gained traction among policymakers and researchers as a valuable tool for assessing sustainable development.Dasgupta's contributions extend beyond theoretical frameworks to practical policy applications. His work on the economics of climate change has been particularly influential, informing international negotiations and national climate policies. In a collaborative study, Dasgupta and colleagues demonstrated the economic rationale for strong, early action on climate change mitigation (Stern and Dasgupta, 2021).Throughout his career, Dasgupta has emphasized the importance of interdisciplinary approaches to addressing complex environmental and development challenges. His work has bridged the gap between economics, ecology, and other natural sciences, fostering collaboration and knowledge exchange across disciplines (Polasky et al., 2019).Dasgupta's influence extends beyond academia to policy-making and public discourse. He has served as an advisor to numerous governments and international organizations, including the World Bank and the United Nations. His work has been instrumental in shaping global sustainable development goals and strategies for achieving them (Sachs et al., 2019).In conclusion, Sir Partha Dasgupta's contributions to environmental and development economics have been transformative, reshaping our understanding of the relationship between economic growth, environmental sustainability, and human well-being. His work has not only advanced theoretical frameworks but also provided practical tools for policymakers to address some of the most pressing challenges of our time. As the world grapples with issues such as climate change, biodiversity loss, and sustainable development, Dasgupta's insights continue to be highly relevant and influential.
